thread.title: Horror fest goes back to original model
thread.title_full: Horror fest goes back to original model

title: Horror fest goes back to original model
text: Home > Entertainment > Movie Previews, Reviews Horror fest goes back to original model October 15, 2015 01:01 AM "Super Still"ERIE TIMES-NEWS October 15, 2015 01:01 AM SEE ITThe 12th Annual Eerie Horror Film Festival will be held Friday through Sunday at the Warner Theatre. Day pass is $15 on Friday, $20 on Saturday and $10 on Sunday. All-access passes are $40. The expo and special guest sections are open Friday, 4-10 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m.-10 p.m.; Sunday, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. Screenings are Friday, 4 p.m.-1:30 a.m.; Saturday, 10:30 a.m.-1:30 a.m.; and Sunday, 10:30 a.m.-5:30 p.m.Horror fest nomineesBelow is a list of nominees for Eerie Horror Film Festival with a synopsis, run time, country of origin and time block for each movie, courtesy of the fest. The categories are for best film and best actor, etc., not "best beheading" or "best exorcism." For details on other films and the complete schedule, scare up www.eeriehorrorfilmfestival.com on your computer, tablet, phone or 8 ball.BEST FILM"Julia" This neon-noir revenge thriller centers on Julia Shames, who falls prey to an unorthodox form of therapy to restore herself after a brutal trauma. 1:35. U.S. Saturday, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m."III" After Mira falls ill during an epidemic, her sister turns to a shaman for a cure that require complete immersion into the patient's mind -- a journey into the deepest, most hidden depths of the subconscious. 1:20. German/Russian Federation. Friday, 4-6 p.m."Savageland"When a small town near the Arizona-Mexico border is wiped out overnight, suspicion falls on the survivor. Photos the survivor took that night tell a different story. 1:22. U.S. Saturday, 9:30-11:30 p.m."Last Girl Standing"Five years after a psychotic slasher killed her friends, Camryn -- racked with paranoia and survivor's guilt -- meets a co-worker who tries to integrate her into his circle. Just when things look up, her past comes back to haunt her. 1:30. U.S. Saturday, 3:30-5:30 p.m."All I Need" An insecure young woman must overcome her captor to save her life, all the while not knowing the sinister reason why she's being held. 1:25. U.S. Saturday, 1-3 p.m."Bigfoot the Movie"Guns and beer are in big supply in this comedy/horror film that skewers Pittsburgh stereotypes and the Bigfoot myth. U.S. 1:35. Saturday, 7-9 p.m. BEST SHORTS"Liar"A first date with a woman who turns out to be a pathological liar only gets worse as the night goes on. 14:52. Australia. Saturday, 12 a.m.-1:30 a.m. Bad Guy #2 Moving up in a crime ring has its downside for one thug who must set an example or become one in this splatter comedy. 9:55. U.S. Saturday, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m."The Trap" A man invites his friend over to show off his latest invention, a trap for catching aliens. 2:03. U.S. Friday, 6:30-8:30 p.m. "In The Basement" A man hellbent on creating a family by kidnapping women may have picked the wrong girl, this time. 13:24. U.S. Saturday, 1-3 p.m."Lifeline" An enigmatic traveler visits a psychic parlor, where an ailing palm reader is compelled to take the future into her own hands. 17:39. U.S. Friday, 4-6 p.m."Recovery"James has survived a zombie-flu outbreak, but he's guilt-ridden and must come to terms with horrific actions he can't remember. 17:24. South Africa. Saturday, 3:30-5:30 p.m.Best directorBenjamin R. Moody, "Last Girl Standing"Matthew McGregor, "In the Basement"Phil Guidry, Simon Hebert, David Whelan, "Savageland"Matthew A. Brown, "Julia"Jared Show, "Bigfoot the Movie"Dick Grunert, "The Trap"Alexandra Neary, "In The Basement"Sara Zanelletti, "Normalcy"Morgan Wright, "What's Eating Dad"Akasha Villalobos, "Last Girl Standing"Lynn Lowry, "Model" Curt Wooton, "Bigfoot the Movie"Pessi Kivilä-Pimeällä, "Polulla" Despite good intentions, the Eerie Horror Film Festival evolved over the years into a Jekyll & Hyde affair, a veritable two-headed monster, a real-life Bette and Dot act like in 2014's "American Horror Story: Freak Show." Fest creator and President Greg Ropp realized the event increasingly appealed to two different camps: Those who like scary movies, and those who like to meet special guests such as Norman Reedus, one of 2011's zombie killers. For 2015, Ropp decided to emphasize one facet -- the movies. "This is a getting-back-to-the-roots year," Ropp said. "What I mean is, over the years, we've been trying to do a film fest and a convention at the same time, which worked gloriously well for a few years. "We created a monster. There were people who came who could care less about film and people who came to the films who could care less about the guests. We were trying to branch out into pleasing everyone." Though the emphasis is back on films, guests will appear this weekend, including actors Lynn Lowry, Tiffany Shepis and Chris Hahn. "We're back to having guests who are there for a reason -- specifically if they have a film showing or some sort of promoting tie-in," Ropp said. That said, Ropp still plans to bring big names to Erie. He hopes to start a pop-culture convention that would focus on fan interaction with stars from film and TV. Luring top names in spring -- as opposed to October, when horror and sci-fi actors are in high demand -- should be easier. "Case in point, we've tried to get people like Linda Blair, and their signing fees go up and become cost prohibitive," Ropp said. "Celebs realize Erie is not Los Angeles. It makes more sense to do something not in October but later, when prices come down and availability goes up. So, we're looking to a full-fledged pop-culture convention, still with horror, but also sci-fi, fantasy and more importantly, classic TV stars." That won't happen until spring 2016 or 2017, however. This weekend, then, focuses on horror films with a varied collection of shorts and features from around the world. They vary in approach: monsters, psychological horror, repressed memories, killer breasts. "It's really one of our best years for quality of movies," said John Walkiewicz, the vice-president of the Eerie Horror Film Festival. "Most of them were scored very highly by our judges. There are some with recognizable stars. "Our Saturday night movie, 'Bigfoot the Movie,' stars Curtis Wooten, who plays Pittsburgh Dad on YouTube. 'The Good Word' has an actor (Conleth Hill, aka Lord Varys) from 'Game of Thrones.' 'Julia,' which plays Saturday, is getting a theatrical release. But we're showing the unrated version; it'll be the R-rated one in theaters." "Julia" stars Ashley C. Williams, who was in the first "The Human Centipede." More than 30 countries submitted films, and several filmmakers -- including Gregory Lamberson ("Killer Rack") -- will introduce their movies. "We're focusing more on the films this year, so we don't have any real big names coming out," Walkiewicz said. "First and foremost, it's an independent film festival. That's our main focus, and the celebrities are secondary." SEE ITThe 12th Annual Eerie Horror Film Festival will be held Friday through Sunday at the Warner Theatre. Day pass is $15 on Friday, $20 on Saturday and $10 on Sunday. All-access passes are $40. The expo and special guest sections are open Friday, 4-10 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m.-10 p.m.; Sunday, 10 a.m.-6 p.m. Screenings are Friday, 4 p.m.-1:30 a.m.; Saturday, 10:30 a.m.-1:30 a.m.; and Sunday, 10:30 a.m.-5:30 p.m.Horror fest nomineesBelow is a list of nominees for Eerie Horror Film Festival with a synopsis, run time, country of origin and time block for each movie, courtesy of the fest. The categories are for best film and best actor, etc., not "best beheading" or "best exorcism." For details on other films and the complete schedule, scare up www.eeriehorrorfilmfestival.com on your computer, tablet, phone or 8 ball.BEST FILM"Julia" This neon-noir revenge thriller centers on Julia Shames, who falls prey to an unorthodox form of therapy to restore herself after a brutal trauma. 1:35.
